body:
Comment 5: 
Yes, but rarely. Usually there's only zero or one parameter in practice.  And there's a
nice fast path for saying that a parameter doesn't exist:  !string.Contains(string(t),
p)  I don't think we'd have to do too much repetitive parsing of the parameters.

If callers were actually performance sensitive, they can call Params() and get them all
at one.  I doubt most callers would care, though.
